description.en: Introduction of the key topics concerning animal minds, such as, among others, mental representation, reasoning, metacognition, consciousness, communication.
description.et: Tutvustatakse põhilisi loomade vaimu puudutavaid filosoofilisi küsimusi, mille hulka kuuluvad näiteks mentaalne esitus, arutlemine, metakognitsioon, teadvus, kommunikatsioon.

objectives.en: This course aims to give a general overview of the key topics concerning animal mentality.
objectives.et: Õppeaine annab ülevaate loomade vaimu puudutavatest filosoofia võtmeteemadest.

learning_outcomes.en: After passing the course, the student has acquired:
-	familiarity with the basics of the philosophy of animal minds,
-	knowledge of the main philosophical issues on animal mentality,
learning_outcomes.et: -	teadlik peamistest loomade vaimu puudutavatest filosoofilistest küsimustest,

independent_work.et: Students must choose at least one chapter/reading to present (if they prefer, they can make a presentation with slides, but it is not mandatory. The slides can be shared with others on Moodle).

description.et:
Attendance and Participation (40%+20% of the final grade)
- Max two missed seminars allowed.

Discussion of at least one reading (40% of the final grade)
- Presentation of at least one reading/chapter (if the students do not present at least one reading, they cannot pass the course).

grade_preconditions.et:
1. Attendance and active participation (max two missed seminars allowed).
2. Presentation of at least one reading (if the students do not present at least one reading, they cannot pass the course).

grade_evaluation.et:
To pass the course, the following results must be obtained:
- Attendance 40%
- Participation 20%
- Presentation of at least one reading 40%

resources.mandatory_materials:
Each student must choose one reading from the provided list, and the same reading cannot be selected more than once. Each selected reading should be presented in class.

 Andrews, K. (2015). Teaching animals language. In The animal mind: An introduction to the philosophy of animal cognition. Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group.
    Bearzi, G., Eddy, L., Piwetz, S., Reggente, M.A.L., Cozzi, B. (2017). Cetacean Behavior Toward the Dead and Dying. In: Vonk, J., Shackelford, T. (eds) Encyclopedia of Animal Cognition and Behavior. Springer, Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-47829-6_2023-1
    Beck, J. (2018). Do nonhuman animals have a language of thought? In K. Andrews & J. Beck (Eds.), The Routledge Handbook of Philosophy of Animal Minds (pp. 46-55). Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group. https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315742250-5
    Boesch, C. (1991). Teaching among wild chimpanzees. Animal Behaviour, 41(3), 530-532. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0003-3472(05)80857-7
    Bugnyar T. (2013). Social cognition in ravens. Comparative cognition & behavior reviews, 8, 1-12. https://doi.org/10.3819/ccbr.2013.80001
    Clayton N. (2007). Animal cognition: crows spontaneously solve a metatool task. Current biology: CB, 17(20), R894-R895. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2007.08.028
    de Waal, F., Wright, R., Korsgaard, C. M., Kitcher, P., & Singer, P. (2006). Anecdotes of changing places in fancy/Consolation behaviour. In Primates and Philosophers: How Morality Evolved (S. Macedo & J. Ober, Eds.). Princeton University Press. http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt7tbch
    Dror S, Miklósi Á, Sommese A, Temesi A, Fugazza C. (2021) Acquisition and long-term memory of object names in a sample of gifted Word Learner dogs. R. Soc. Open Sci. 8:210976. https://doi.org/10.1098/rsos.210976 
    Gardner, R. A., & Gardner, B. T. (1969). Teaching Sign Language to a Chimpanzee. Science, 165(3894), 664-672. http://www.jstor.org/stable/1727877
    Goldsborough, Z., Schel Anne Marijke and van Leeuwen Edwin J.C. (2023), Chimpanzees communicate to coordinate a cultural practice. Proc. R. Soc. B. 290: 20221754. https://doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2022.1754
    Gruen, L. (2018). Empathy in mind. In The Routledge Handbook of Philosophy of Animal Minds (pp. 485-490). Taylor and Francis.
    Inoue, S., and Matsuzawa, T. (2007). Working memory of numerals in chimpanzees. Curr. Biol. 17(23), R1004-R1005
    Jamieson, D. (2018). Animals and ethics, agents and patients. In The Routledge Handbook of Philosophy of Animal Minds (pp. 461-468). Taylor and Francis. https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315742250
    Martin-Ordas, G., Haun, D., Colmenares, F., & Call, J. (2010). Keeping track of time: evidence for episodic-like memory in great apes. Animal cognition, 13(2), 331-340. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10071-009-0282-4

    Reinhard J. (2015). Animal cognition: bumble bees suffer 'false memories'. Current biology: CB, 25(6), R236-R238. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2015.01.072
    Saidel, E. (2018). On psychological explanations and self-concepts (in some animals). In K. Andrews & J. Beck (Eds.), The Routledge Handbook of Philosophy of Animal Minds (pp. 131-141). Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group. https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315742250-13
